The Volkswagen example really hits home. I remember when that story broke and thinking about all the engineers who must have known something was wrong. I don't want to be in their position years from now, wondering why I didn't speak up when I had the chance.

I'm going to start with filing that internal report today, like you suggested. Even if I'm skeptical about the outcome, at least I'll have that documentation. And I'll reach out to a whistleblower attorney this week to understand my options better.

One last question though - I keep going back to those emails showing executives knew about this. If they're already aware and haven't acted, doesn't that suggest the internal reporting is just going to be a formality? Part of me wonders if I should skip straight to external reporting since we're already past the point where this could be an innocent mistake or oversight.

What's your take on that? Am I being naive to think internal channels might work when there's evidence of executive knowledge?

<END>
